posts.author: JimDandy
posts.content:
Hei, gang!

I'd like to have a couple of dwarf brothers on WoG; one is a greataxe, barbarian-ish, brute kinda guy who loves to leap into battle without regard for his own safety. The other a holy warrior, wise priest, healing-his-brother-all-the-time, warhammer and shield kinda guy, perhaps dwarven defender-ish. The two are a bit opposite of each other and argue like crazy, but love each other to death - they are both very protective, of each other and of their party members, and so will always insist on going in first. The two of them in the same party is a guaranteed stuck pair of dwarves in the doorway! I'd like to see the feat selections for each represent their personalities and combat styles. I've put together what I could think of to make them thematical, I'd love your input and expert help on making final builds of them! (RDD is not an option for these guys.)

Joe-Jim Toughstone
Barbarian melee mentality; think dwarven berserker, battlerager. I once posted an ancient attempt at this guy, lol! >.<

Famous Last Words: "Me first!"

Desired primary attributes in order of prioritization:
  • STR
  • CON
Desired classes:
  • Barbarian (preferably, 16 or more)
  • Fighter (4 or more)
  • Optional: Whatever else might work thematically and with the Barbarian alignment requirement (no opposing multiclassing, as you WoG'ers know). Weapon Master is an option, though I fear the feats (and DEX and INT requiresments) might be a bit too demanding for little return on investment. I mention it as it could be useful if many levels were taken so that he could really devot himself to that greataxe and apply the Improved Power Attack feat a lot - I understand there's quite a bit of AB to gain from high WM levels. "That's soooo Joe-Jim!" Rogue is also another option.
Desired feats are:
  • Optional/Thematic: Strong Soul
  • WF/EWF: Greataxe
  • WS/EWS: Greataxe
  • Power Attack
  • Cleave
  • Great Cleave
  • Improved Critical
  • Overwhelming Critical
  • Devastating Critical
  • Optional/Thematic: Improved Power Attack
  • Knockdown
  • Optional/Thematic: Toughness
  • Optional/Thematic: Great Fortitude
  • Optional/Thematic: Epic Fortitude
  • EDRIII
Tolkien Toughstone
The wiser brother, with a bit of a Lawful Stupid mentality showing itself when he insists on going first to protect everyone else. I don't know clerics well so I'm not sure what feats are good for them, and I am not sure what might be considered "a must" in WoG. He needs to be able to hold himself in melee really well; being a cleric, that shouldn't be awfully hard to accomplish. I'd like to have him be outstanding at something that represents his personality, too. It's a plus if it's an opposite or compliment to Joe-Jim, like a super good healer - or something like getting a certain school of spell through, no matter what. He is primarily a caster, not a meleer. I'm also interested in more "unusual cleric feats" selections, perhaps; like Scribe Scroll, maybe Craft Wand, etc.

Famous Last Words: "I should proably be handlin' this 'ere situation, lads."

Desired primary attributes in order of prioritization:
  • WIS
  • CON
  • STR
Desired deities:
  • Moradin
  • Clangeddin Silverbeard
 
I know that we are only allowing for two domains per deity although most have more than that, but this is for scripting purposes and one of those things we will need to deal with. Here are the rules you MUST follow to be a cleric:
1) You must set your deity. If you did not do this on your creation, either remake your PC OR visit the altar of worship in the temple in Borderkeep.
2) You must also spell the deity as it is shown.
3) You must choose from the following alignment and domain restrictions.
4) You must adhere to the race restrictions.

Moradin
To serve as a cleric of Moradin, you must be Lawful Good, Lawful Neutral, or Neutral Good dwarf and must take the Earth and Good domain feats.

Clangeddin Silverbeard
To serve as a cleric of Clangeddin Silverbeard, you must be Lawful, Neutral or Chaotic Good and must take the Strength and War domain feats.
 
Desired classes:
  • Cleric
  • Optional: Paladin
  • Optional: Dwarven Defender
  • Optional: Fighter
​Desired feats:
  • Optional/Thematic: Strong Soul
  • WF/EWF: Warhammer
  • Optional/Thematic: Toughness
  • Optional/Thematic: Iron Will
  • Optional/Thematic: Epic Will
  • Optional/Thematic: EDRIII
  • Spell Penetration
  • Greater Spell Penetration
  • Epic Spell Penetration
  • Spell Focus
  • Greater Spell Focus
  • Epic Spell Focus
Thanks in advance!


​-JimDandy

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content: The reason most Cleric-Warrior builds are going for exact 15 BAB pre-epic is that when they cast Divine Power afterwards the extra attack that comes once the spell resets your BAB to that of a Warrior (20 instead of 15) comes at the highest attack bonus of your character instead of giving you an extra attack at the last sequence. For example if you had let's say an attack routine of (40/ 35/ 30) with your Cleric, once you cast Divine Power this goes to (45/ 45/ 40/ 35) giving you essentially an extra attack with a +15 AB bonus.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
That's a cool build Jim and we can make it work as it is if you like, but before that let's take a good look at it.

1st) You are attempting to build a non-Human warrior with both weapon master and devastating critical pre-requisites. That's about 10 pre-epic feats right there only to be able to qualify for those things.

2nd) I am assuming here that this warrior will make his share of solo play. Without a class like Rogue inside the build you are going to miss major things out from the lack of UMD and not only that but your AC is currently 4 worse because you can only have 20 ranks in tumble as oppose to 40 a rogue would allow you to take. For solo play AC must be high, especially on WoG since you don't have the redeming qualities of a true Barbarian build. Your DR is only 3 points and your hit points aren't exactly that high. Moreover you miss ranks in spellcraft.

My Advice: Forget the weapon master for this build. Replace him with rogue or bard levels. If you truly want to take that route then let go of Dev. Critical, logic says that a two-handed strength-based warrior with WM augmented criticals will obliterate his foes very quickly anyway, so Dev. Critical is not really a need but a luxury. Basically it's one thing or the other, having both in the same build absorbs your feat like a huge sponge delaying too much the growth of your character.

***** Voice Of Logic Ends*****

Having said that, i am all for personalizing your characters and forgeting the optimum builds as long as the build makes that "click" to me. Let's try to optimize a bit the "Toughstone" brother as it is with him having both weapon master and devastating critical into the build. If we can't make it, then at least we tried ;)

1) Move Blind fight and Expertise closer to the start of the build. Power attack and cleave can wait.
2) Take Terrifying Rage as soon as possible, you can take it at lvl 30 from what i see in your build. Move Overwhelming/ Devastating Critical after the Terrifying Rage. Yes, the rage is that good.
3) Forget Thundering Rage entirely, not worth the general epic feat it occupies.Take Epic fortitude instead.
4) Forget Taunt, you don't need it at all with that AB and move those ranks into Spellcraft instead, which is vastly more important.

That's all i can see for now man, i will wait for an updated version of your build,

Go go Toughstone Brothers!

Haha, thank you for the inspiring words! You are completely correct on all counts, I will add. I will reply to the points in the order you made them.
1) It's Greataxe critical maximizing, with Barbarian for Terrifying Rage and Thundering Rage. All feats were chosen as a way to show it could be done and to make the sum of feat selections the thematic part (instead of individual thematic feats - Strong Soul, Toughness, Great Fortitude, Epic Fortitude, etc. - and many other "plain good ones").

2) I really dislike losing out on EDRIII on this fellow, especially since he won't be able to soak up damage from having a two-hander and no shield, and no maxed Tumble.

Responding to your "Voice of Logic" advice:
I'm honestly wanting to see a version that neither take Devastating Critical nor Weapon Master levels (hence, why I was drawn to the Bear Warrior), where I don't even take Improved Critical: Greataxe. Essentially, saving a lot of feats on completely avoiding trying to score critical hits, and just getting AB and Damage Output as high as possible. This would be more of how Joe-Jim would be; he doesn't care to try to score critical hits. If they happen, they happen. He'd rather be chopping away tirelessly with a very high AB and Damage Output than trying to think, if that makes sense. However, I'd agree to raising his INT to a 10 for better skill points, and to go Barbarian/Fighter/Rogue - I'd probably not like Rogue in pre-epics; the only save that's important to him is the Fortitude save - that is definitely a thematical point about him that I'd love to get back to. Also - and this I love in WoG - he's meant to primarily use a Maul (two-handed hammer), so if I could get his AB high enough I would even - for thematic reasons - ditch Weapon Focus: Greataxe, and maybe allow him a Warhammer and Shield combo, with EWF/EWS: Warhammer (like his brother might come to have). Sadly, the feats for WF, WS, EFS, EWS, WoC, etc., aren't enabled for the Maul (though they could be, with some drawbacks - I'll post about it on WoG's forums). I currently like the Bear Warrior more for Joe-Jim, and my posted build more for one of their other clanmembers that would be an NPC, hahahah.

That said, here's how I'd continue staying true to that.
1) & 2): Yea!
3) I had chosen Thundering Rage to try to keep some of the thematic Battlerager in him. Clearly, the chosen path is spending almost every single feat on his weapon, and so many of them are all about critical hits from that greataxe! It felt silly not to include the very last one of them for those reason. I know it stacks with everything but a massive critical property on a weapon (as I understand it, that's because Thundering Rage applies that very property, temporarily, on the weapon in the right hand). Thus, this one is hard for me to give up in this particular devoted path of the Greataxe. However, in almost any other variation of this build; hell yea, I'd ditch it - looks like there might be 3 brothers, bwahahahah! J/K ;) And, I'd be able to cut the Barbarian levels down to 15 instead of 17, as Thundering Rage and Terrifying Rage both needed to be taken on a Barbarian level, and after level 15 when the Greater Rage x 4 requirement was met - if there was a way to take them both at the same level at level 15, I missed it.
4) Yea!

What about these three options to potentially replace the two Great Strength feats?:
- Epic Skill Focus: Intimidate for Terrifying Rage buff.
- Improved Power Attack for thematic purposes; but is it actually useful, too? If it's completely useless because of the -10 to-hit, then I don't care how thematic it is - it'd not be part of the build. However, you said in 4) that the AB is so high, Taunt isn't needed at all. If Taunt is kept, does it also make IPA more viable?
- Epic Fortitude vs. either of the above two feats?

I'll post another revision based on The Bear Warrior today, with what I said in the advice-reply as the variation, and based on what you said on page 1: 1st Brother) Barbarian 24/ Rogue 10/ Fighter 6, with Terrifying Rage, Crippling Strike, EWS, Devastating Critical, brandishing a Great Axe. But, without Devastating Critical, and possibly without any Weapon Focus whatsoever (he's more generic about his violence that way ;)).

Thanks for staying with it!


-JimDandy

Alright, to the Toughstone brothers once more, Jim i pointed my finger at Thundering rage exactly because it become irrelevant if you also have Overwhelming critical or even a massive critical property in your weapon of choice. The thundering  rage bonusses sadly do not stack with anything at all In place of this feat,definitely take Epic Fortitude (can be anything though) as it is also in the theme of the character and vital for his survival. The mages on WoG aren't joking, they detect automatically what immunities and whatnot you have and try to terminate you with Finger of death, Wail of the banshee and if you are immune to those, then with Flesh to stone! Now, all of these spells are fortitude saves, so you understand why i advocated the Epic Fortitude feat for the "Tough" brothers.

Improved Power Attack is marginally useful at best, i wouldn't waste a feat on this unless i had a spare one, which is not the case here. And whatever you do, do not lower further the strength of your barbarian! ESF: Intimidate is a welcoming addition but a luxury in your case, let's be frank here, you cannot afford it! Do not worry though, the normal maximum ranks plus a clever item or two will be more than enough.

That's all man, i will be waiting to see your revised build then.

And whatever you do, do not lower further the strength of your barbarian! ESF: Intimidate is a welcoming addition but a luxury in your case, let's be frank here, you cannot afford it! Do not worry though, the normal maximum ranks plus a clever item or two will be more than enough.

That's all man, i will be waiting to see your revised build then.
This is from the NWN Wiki, on stacking the Thundering Rage with Overwhelming Critical. I havent' tested it myself, but the stuff on the Wiki is usually very solid: 
  • The additional damage is implemented as a massive critical item property, one which will not be applied if the weapon already has such a property. (In particular, it stacks with overwhelming critical.)
I'll work on the revised build tonight. All the knowledge I've been picking up lately has steered me towards an Elf (drow) concept that I'd like to flesh out and see if there aren't already acceptable builds of. It really helped a lot to write the character concepts/definitions down!

As far as Tolkien Toughstone goes, I do wish for a caster-cleric more than a melee. Bone Breaker looks like a lot of fun, for sure, but I'd love to experience more from the Cleric. I've always enjoyed themed clerics, a la Undead Slayers or Healers, Protectors; more defensive that offensive, I think, but like I said he should still able to hold his own in melee thanks to just being able to tap into all the raw power from divine spells and wear fullplate and a tower shield.

Your The Bear Warrior is my fallback for Joe-Jim, with just flavor tweaks. The Greataxe Psycho version is what it is and will be some distant cousin of theirs. ;) I'm only trying one more concept of Joe-Jim before I decide and move on to the cleric build for Tolkien Toughstone, and that is a tweak on the Bloodred Vengeance build by Grimnir77, where I'm playing around with Barbarian 15/ Ranger 21/ Fighter 4. It seems to have merit for the concept; I could see Joe-Jim ranger-roaming both inside the mountain and on the mountain (that's how he got in so much trouble all the time). EWS Greataxe, EDRIII, Bane of Enemies, and Terrifying Rage, clad in fullplate; he should be fun!

Breaktime from the dwarves; got another build idea distracting me for attention!
